tossups.question: Two rulers of this name faced revolts by Horwennefer. A ruler of this name faced a revolt by his half-brother Magas, who occupied a neighboring kingdom known for producing silphium. A ruler of this name supposedly placed 72 Jewish scholars in separate rooms, with each producing an identical Torah translation, forming the Septuagint. A ruler of this name ousted his brother who shared this name, Keraunos. For breaking a (*) siege by Demetrius Poliorcetes, the Rhodians gave a ruler of this name the epithet “Savior,” or Soter. That ruler of this name commissioned a 300-foot-tower on the island of Pharos, founded the cult of Serapis, and set plans for a monumental library at Alexandria. For 10 points, give this name shared by 15 Egyptian pharaohs of Hellenistic origin.
tossups.answer: Ptolemy [or Ptolemaios; accept Ptolemaic dynasty or Ptolemaioi; accept Ptolemy I Soter; accept Ptolemy II Philadelphus the Great; accept Ptolemy IV Philopator; accept Ptolemy V Epiphanes Eucharistos; accept Ptolemy II Keraunos]

tossups.question: These objects are not orbs or flowers, but they title a 2019 Yayoi Kusama work that consists of 90 stainless steel masses covering a gallery floor. These objects were briefly created in gallery spaces and photographed for a series by the Dutch artist Berndnaut Smilde. Merce Cunningham’s “RainForest” choreography involves dancers interacting with silvery pieces of a work named for these objects, which were lent to Cunningham by (*) Andy Warhol. A torso, a tuba, and a chair in Rene Magritte’s Menacing Weather appear to be made of these objects, which he also depicted in an eye in The False Mirror. This is the first word in the official title of a sculpture in Millennium Park by Anish Kapoor. For 10 points, Chicago’s “The Bean” is formally known as a “Gate” of what objects?
tossups.answer: clouds [accept Cloud Gate; accept Silver Clouds]

tossups.question: A character in this novel feels his soul “trembling all over” and touching the spiritual “other worlds” his teacher spoke of on his deathbed after seeing that teacher in a dream. That character in this novel has a vivid childhood memory of being held up to an icon at sunset by his mother, who is called the “shrieker” because of her mental breakdowns. In this novel’s epilogue, a character gives “The Speech at the Stone” after the funeral of a boy who had once violently (*) bitten his finger when he interfered in a stone-throwing fight. In this novel, Father Ferapont exorcises a rival monk’s corpse due to its stench. A church official praises the devil for the three questions he asked to tempt Christ in this novel’s chapter “The Grand Inquisitor.” For 10 points, name this Fyodor Dostoyevsky novel about Dmitri, Ivan, and Alexei.
tossups.answer: The Brothers Karamazov [or The Karamazov Brothers; or Bratya Karamazovy]

tossups.question: “Lionheart” and “Maverick” were two nicknames for an early 2000s holder of this position, whose Bush- aligned foreign policy led to the controversial deployment of an Iraq Reconstruction and Support Group. A holder of this position introduced a 1960 plan to double his country’s income in 10 years in part as a distraction from the Anpo protests. The “1955 System” refers to the success of a party in nearly (*) monopolizing this position for the last 60 years. A holder of this position legislated a constitution whose Article 9 “forever renounces war.” A holder of this position implemented a policy of “three arrows,” including monetary easing, as part of his namesake “-nomics.” For 10 points, name this highest position held by members of the Liberal Democratic Party such as Shinzō Abe.
tossups.answer: Prime Minister of Japan [or Nihon-koku naikaku sōridaijin or shushō; or PM of Japan, accept PMOJ; prompt on Prime Minister or PM] (The unnamed prime ministers are Jun'ichirō Koizumi, Shigeru Yoshida, and Hayato Ikeda.)

tossups.question: A butcher is ordered to punch the queen of this region in the head every day, stopping only when a starling brings her father a message. A sociopath systematically murders two hundred warriors of this region as they hide in bags of meal before bursting his heart while destroying a magic cauldron. After traveling to this region, the giant Bran the Blessed dies fighting its king (*) Matholwch (“MATH-al-ook”) for mistreating Branwen. Culhwch (“KIL-hook”) traveled to this island to engage the boar Twrch Trwyth (“TOORK TROO-eth”) before it crossed the sea to Cornwall. One of this region’s heroes fished up and ate the Salmon of Knowledge. For 10 points, name this island opposed to Britain in the Mabinogion, whose own mythology follows Cu Chulainn (“koo HUL-in”) and Finn MacCool.
tossups.answer: Ireland [or Éire; or Iwerddon; accept Ulster]

tossups.question: The success rate of cultures of these cells can be improved by co-culturing them with STO cells or other “feeder” lines. The CD133 marker is used to isolate a subtype of cancer cells named in analogy for these cells due their similar usage of pathways like Notch. One type of these cells was discovered by Till and McCulloch via the observation that splenic nodule size varied linearly with the number of cells injected from irradiated (*) bone marrow. These cells are produced by the introduction of Oct4, Sox2, and other Yamanaka factors to adult cells. These cells perpetually retain the ability to proliferate while maintaining pluripotency. For 10 points, name these undifferentiated cells that include a subtype controversially harvested from developing embryos.
tossups.answer: stem cells [accept adult stem cells or induced pluripotent stem cells or embryonic stem cells or hematopoietic stem cells; prompt on iPSCs or ESCs or ASCs or HSCs]

tossups.question: In 2021, General Motors announced plans to extract lithium from this geographical feature with the Hell’s Kitchen project. The Sonny Bono Bird Refuge is near this body of water, and is an important stopping ground for migrating birds on the Pacific Flyway. Tourist attractions near this body of water include East Jesus, an art installation made entirely of waste, and Salvation Mountain, a 50-foot-tall man-made mountain covered in paint. (*) Bombay Beach was a popular resort destination near this body of water in the 1960s, although by the 1980s tourism had dried up due to contamination. This lake was created by mistake in 1905 when irrigation canals from the Colorado River overflowed for two years. For 10 points, name this extremely polluted lake with very high salinity in Southern California.
tossups.answer: Salton Sea

tossups.question: A character with this profession uses the chat room handle “BiGuy” to proposition teenage boys in a Stephen Karam play. In another play, a former actress who was mentored by Sir Henry is sent abroad by her niece, who has this profession. A girl who stole Helen Burton’s bracelet is blackmailed into lying about two people in this profession, causing them to lose a libel case. One of those characters in this profession is told by the other that “I loved you the way they said” after a break-up with the (*) doctor Joe Cardin. After two men with this profession discuss a character’s “hysterical pregnancy,” they play games like “Bringing Up Baby” with Honey and Martha. For 10 points, name this profession of Bertram Cates, who is put on trial in Inherit the Wind for including evolution in his biology lessons.
tossups.answer: teachers [accept high school drama teachers or biology teachers; accept history professors or biology professors; accept schoolteachers] (In order of appearance, the unnamed plays are Stephen Karam’s Speech & Debate, Lillian Hellman’s The Children’s Hour, and Edward Albee’s Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?)

tossups.question: Labs with an older model of these devices like the Beckman XL-I may have to handle output from a Rayleigh interferometer or Schlieren photography system. Running a several hour scan on one of these devices in equilibrium mode may allow experimental determination of buoyant mass. The action of these devices on diethyl zinc produces the corrosion inhibitor DZO. These devices may be used as elutriators for separation of cells by (*) size. Samples are given a flat upper surface when these devices make use of a swinging bucket, which may be filled with empty tubes to ensure balance. These devices are essential for characterizing colloid systems like blood. For 10 points, name these devices which separate fluids by rotating at high speed.
tossups.answer: centrifuges [or centrifugation; accept analytical ultracentrifuges; prompt on AUC]

tossups.question: Christopher Ruhm has documented how these events shifted from being “good for your health” prior to 2000 to uncorrelated with mortality in recent years. To highlight the disparate gender impact of one of these events, a working paper by Alon et al. prepends the word “she” to them instead of “man.” These events are highlighted in gray on graphs produced by the St. Louis-based database FRED (“fred”). The (*) NBER (“EN-burr”) hosts a committee that determines the dates when these events start and end. One of these events marked the conclusion of the “Great Moderation,” which included a mild one of them after the dot-com bubble. For 10 points, subprime mortgage lending is considered a leading factor in the “Great” example of what event from 2007 to 2009?
tossups.answer: recessions [accept the Great Recession or the COVID-19 Recession; prompt on financial crisis; reject “depressions”]

tossups.question: The façade of one of these buildings features a sculpture that was attacked with a bottle of ink for its nude figures. After the section of the Ringstrasse in front of one of these buildings was raised by a meter, residents of Vienna nicknamed it the “sunken treasure chest.” Profits from the rubber boom funded the construction of a building of this type named for the Amazon in Manaus. Colorful ceiling painting by (*) Marc Chagall surround a massive chandelier in one of these places, where Isidore Pils’s sculpture The Triumph of Apollo and several onyx balconies look down upon a white marble “Grand Staircase.” The Palais Garnier is one of these buildings. For 10 points, name this sort of building exemplified by a “shelled” one designed by Jørn Utzon on Sydney Harbor.
tossups.answer: opera houses [accept Sydney Opera House; accept Paris Opera or Opéra de Paris; accept Vienna State Opera or Wiener Staatsoper; prompt on theaters or performing arts centers or auditoriums or concert halls by asking “what specific performances are the theaters intended for?”; prompt on palaces or palais]

tossups.question: In 1956, the Aeromedical Laboratory injected 101 of these people with iodine-131. These people included the alumni of Sheldon Jackson College who formed a “Brotherhood” and “Sisterhood” that led boycotts to pass a 1945 Anti-Discrimination Act under leaders like Elizabeth Peratrovich. In 1966, 300 representatives of these people, like Willie Hensley, formed a “federation” that ensured their hiring on an 800-mile (*) pipeline project. A 1971 “claims settlement act” let these people establish 13 regional corporations in areas like the salmon-rich Bristol Bay borough. These Americans, who meet at the Tanana Chiefs Conference, include the Tsimshian (“SIM-shee-un”), Yupik, Iñupiat, and Tlingit. For 10 points, the census distinguishes American Indians from what Indigenous people of the “Last Frontier”?
tossups.answer: ​Alaska Natives [or Native Alaskans; accept Inuit; accept Iñupiat or Yupik or Tlingit or Tsimshian until each is read; accept Cup’ik or Alutiiq or Sugpiaq or Eyak or Haida or Aleut or Unangan or Tanana or Denaʼina or Gwich’in or Kohtʼiin or Hwëch’in or Ahtna or variants of those names; prompt on Athabascans or Dine or variants; prompt on Native Americans or Indigenous people or First Nations by asking “in what U.S. state?”]

tossups.question: One of these objects is stored in Houston while the narrator retrieves a nuclear warhead buried under Tulsa in the essay “Where Am I?” The “is” of “composition” is defined in a U.T. Place paper titled for this sort of object that, like a similarly titled J.J.C. Smart paper, pioneered identity theory. The citizens of China use walkie-talkies to create one of these objects in an example that (*) Ned Block used to criticize functionalism. These objects are imagined to contain a “theater” where it “all comes together” in a model opposed by Daniel Dennett’s “multiple drafts” theory. Hilary Putnam questioned the coherence of a thought experiment in which one of these objects is removed by an “evil scientist.” For 10 points, in that thought experiment, what organ is placed “in a vat”?
tossups.answer: brains [accept brain in a vat or China brain; prompt on minds; prompt on organs or body parts until “organs” is read]

tossups.question: The use of this kind of data as a signature called a JAPH (“J-A-P-H”) was started by Randal Schwartz. “iframe” tags containing a URI (“U-R-I”) to this kind of data are common XSS vectors. This kind of data may be improved with sugar and fed into a linter. “#! /bin/cat” (“shebang slash bin slash cat”) is an example of this kind of data that trivially quines. Lisp’s choice to represent this kind of data the same way as other sorts is an example of (*) homoiconicity. In dynamic languages, the eval function takes this kind of data as an argument. When this kind of data is interpreted at run-time, comments are ignored. The most common application of version control is to store, for 10 points, what form of data written by developers in languages like JavaScript?
tossups.answer: source code [accept scripts or cross-site scripting; prompt on text or files or strings; prompt on HTML or JavaScript by asking “what kind of data is that?”; prompt on programs, malware, viruses, or malicious software by asking “what kind of data do those contain?”] (JAPH stands for “Just Another Perl Hacker.”)

tossups.question: Roger of Howden chronicled this king’s re-coronation, in which he was crowned beside his mother instead of his wife. Despite an ominous “shower of rain mixed with blood,” this king gave his workers just two years to complete a construction project he referred to as his “daughter," Château Gaillard (“gai-YAHR”). After his sister and his wife Berengaria of Navarre were shipwrecked and taken prisoner by (*) Isaac Komnenos, this king made a detour to conquer Cyprus. After negotiating the Treaty of Jaffa with a rival to end a campaign, this king was imprisoned on the return journey by Leopold of Austria. For 10 points, name this English Plantagenet king who campaigned against Saladin in the Third Crusade, nicknamed for his bravery.
tossups.answer: Richard I Plantagenet [or Richard the Lionhearted or Richard Cœur de Lion; prompt on Richard; prompt on Plantagenet until read]

tossups.question: The narrator of a short story by this author describes a mound-inhabiting creature with two genders who stops hunting honeybees after one stings it. In another story by this author, a girl insists that she doesn’t sing in Sunday school and learns how to spit up in the air without it falling on her. The protagonist writes on a picture of Christopher Columbus in a novel by this author, who included the interjection (*) “what if the baker won’t let me feel the bread?” in a story that gives its addressee harsh instructions for sweeping the house and washing clothes. The title character leaves her island to become an au pair for Lewis and Mariah in a novel by this creator of the Red Girl and Gwen, who also criticized tourism in A Small Place. For 10 points, name this Antiguan author of Annie John and Lucy.
tossups.answer: Jamaica Kincaid [or Elaine Potter Richardson]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. A poem that compares the mind to a mirror and the body to this place was reversed by Huìnéng  (“h’WAY-nung”) in the poetry contest that won him the title of Sixth Patriarch. At this place, the thought “when there is this, that is” inspired the concept of “dependent origination.” During a rainstorm, the serpent Muchalinda stood over this place, which a man traveled to after accepting porridge from the maid Sujata. A man seated before this (*) object adopted the “earth witness” mudra by touching the ground as he rejected the daughters of the demon Mara. This Ficus religiosa, where a man discovered the “middle way” after rejecting asceticism, is often named for a word meaning “awakening,” bodhi. For 10 points, the Buddha achieved enlightenment under what sort of living object?
tossups.answer: the bodhi tree [accept any answers that indicate the tree or sacred fig where the Buddha achieved enlightenment; accept boddhi or Bodh Gaya until “bodhi” is read; accept Ficus religiosa until read; accept ashvattha or peepal; prompt on the Vajrasana or diamond throne]

tossups.question: Prior to his work on viscoelasticity, Karl Weissenberg invented a device for measuring this quantity that solved the indexing problem via layer line separation. A transformation that makes time-independent Hamiltonians [emphasize] not depend on this quantity can be used to find eigenfrequencies of oscillatory systems. This quantity can be measured precisely using a laser autocollimator or a (*) goniometer. The ratio of a projectile’s maximum height and range is a function of this quantity. The motion of a pendulum reduces to simple harmonic motion under an approximation named for this quantity being small. The formula “180 over pi” is used to convert between two forms of—for 10 points—what quantity that can be measured in radians or degrees?
tossups.answer: angles [accept action-angle coordinates; accept small angle approximation; accept launch angle]

tossups.question: During this symphony’s scherzo, an eighth-note rhythm in the strings marked “Wild!” is repeatedly interrupted by a trumpet with the melody “long F [pause], F, E-flat, D-flat, long C.” This symphony’s opening motif features prominently in the first movement of its composer’s [emphasize] previous symphony. This symphony’s scherzo begins with the horn call “D, F-sharp, long low A,” followed by an ascending five-note motif. That scherzo acts as the second part of this symphony’s (*) three-part structure. Leonard Bernstein conducted a movement from this symphony at the funeral of Robert Kennedy. Four short-short-short-long C-sharps begin the trumpet solo that opens this symphony’s first movement funeral march. For 10 points, name this Gustav Mahler symphony famous for its fourth movement adagietto.
tossups.answer: Symphony No. 5 by Gustav Mahler [or Gustav Mahler’s Fifth Symphony or equivalents; accept Symphony No. 5 or Fifth Symphony or equivalents after “Mahler”]

tossups.question: In a novel, a character with this profession wrote his thesis in Wales while studying under Mrs. Pentstemmon. A man with this profession looks for a copy of John Donne’s “Go and catch a falling star” in Miss Angorian’s home. In another novel, a character hoards books about this profession in Hurtfew Abbey. A character with this profession opposes John Segundus’s plan to found a school of this profession, but takes on a pupil in an alternate history novel set in England during the (*) Napoleonic Wars. Two characters with this profession title Susanna Clarke’s Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell. A member of this profession who experiences time backwards tutors Wart by turning him into animals in The Once and Future King. For 10 points, name this profession of King Arthur’s advisor, Merlyn.
tossups.answer: wizards [accept magicians, warlocks, mages, sorcerers, or enchanters; prompt on descriptions of magic] (The first novel is Howl’s Moving Castle by Diana Wynne Jones.)

bonuses.leadin: A poem about this place describes “little gray feet” that “know no rest” and ends each stanza with the phrase “from street to street.” For 10 points each:
answers: Harlem [accept “Harlem Shadows”; accept “The Harlem Dancer”; prompt on New York City or Manhattan]
Claude McKay [or Festus Claudius McKay]
Langston Hughes [or James Mercer Langston Hughes]
parts: Name this title place of that poem. In another poem, the speaker notes that a dancer in this location “seemed a proudly-swaying palm” before realizing that “her self was not in that strange place.”
“Harlem Shadows” and “The Harlem Dancer” are poems by this Jamaican-American poet who wrote of facing the “murderous, cowardly pack” in “If We Must Die.”
This other Harlem Renaissance poet asked, “What happens to a dream deferred?” in the poem “Harlem.”

bonuses.leadin: “Privileged” persons performing this action in pursuit of “mastery” constitutes the title “problem” of a 1991 paper by Linda Martín Alcoff. For 10 points each:
answers: speaking [or speech; accept “The Problem of Speaking for Others” or “Can the Subaltern Speak?”]
essentialism [accept essentializing]
Luce Irigaray
parts: The image of a “a continuous and homogeneous ‘India’” in colonial sources like Edward Thompson’s book Suttee is discussed in a Gayatri Spivak essay titled for what action?

Alcoff’s essay cites Spivak on the danger of using this attitude to cast the “oppressed” as “non-ideologically constructed subjects.” This is the belief that there are fixed, intrinsic features of categories like race and gender.
This Belgian-born French theorist has claimed that “to speak is never neutral,” and used the chapter “When Our Lips Speak Together” to close her book This Sex Which Is Not One.

bonuses.leadin: Lila Abu-Lughod punned on this sort of object in the title of a book about her time in the home of “the Haj,” a leader of the Awlad ‘Ali community of Bedouins. For 10 points each:
answers: veils [or a headscarf; or a headcovering; prompt on clothing or garments or equivalents]

oral poetry [or epic poetry; accept oral literature or folk literature; accept any answers about performing or composing poems; accept oral storytelling; prompt on word forms of singing, chanting, or reciting; prompt on orality; prompt on literature] (The oral-formulaic theory is about Homeric epics.)
photographs [accept photo-elicitation or photographic analysis; prompt on images or pictures or visuals] (Balinese Character: A Photographic Analysis is by Gregory Bateson and Margaret Mead.)
parts: Name this sort of object exemplified by the tagelmust used by Tuareg men. A word generally meaning “barrier,” hijab, is used to refer to this sort of object in English.

Veiled Sentiments details the techniques of hinnawa, an Egyptian Bedouin type of this activity. Fieldwork in the Balkans inspired the Parry-Lord hypothesis that ancient practitioners of this activity relied on “formulas.”

In the book’s afterword, Abu-Lughod shows the Haj’s household a set of these things she created for the book. An “elicitation” interview technique is named for these things, which are analyzed in the book Balinese Character.

bonuses.leadin: Calibrating these devices often involves flat-fielding and dark subtraction. For 10 points each:
answers: CCDs [or charge-coupled devices]
backwards compatibility [or backward compatibility; prompt on consistency]
Python
parts: Name these imaging devices widely used in astrometry. Images produced by these devices record each pixel value using metal-oxide capacitors that measure photoelectrons liberated by incident light.

CCD images are stored with the FITS file type, which has a simple format to maintain this property. Some astronomers view the IAU’s focus on this property of FITS as restricting its ability to change, with only four versions being released since 1982.

Astrometric analysis of images is often done with scientific libraries like astropy (“astro-PIE”) and matplotlib (“mat-plot-LIB”) in this interpreted programming language which uses whitespace to format its code.

bonuses.leadin: An author with this married surname wrote, “Real poetry lies elsewhere. Far from rhymes, laments … And to hell with hibiscus, frangipani, and bougainvillea” in an essay published in Tropiques. For 10 points each:
answers: Césaire [accept Aimé Césaire or Suzanne Césaire] (The essay is “The Great Camouflage.”)
Nadja
Surrealism [accept Surrealist Manifesto or Manifeste du surréalisme; accept Afro-Surrealism]
parts: Give this surname of an author who calls beauty “the false claim of the stone” in Notebook of a Return to My Native Land.
Suzanne Césaire claimed that “Martinican poetry shall be cannibal or nothing at all,” which likely references the closing line of this novel, “Beauty shall be CONVULSIVE or will not be at all.”

Suzanne Césaire inspired the “Afro-” form of this movement with the credo “permanent readiness for the marvelous.” Nadja’s author, André Breton, wrote a manifesto calling this movement “pure psychic automatism.”

bonuses.leadin: Before this word is sung, a baritone sings, “Oh friends, not these sounds!” and asks for “more pleasing” ones, referring to the first three movements of the piece in which it appears. For 10 points each:
answers: Freude [or joy; accept “Ode to Joy” or “An die Freude”; reject “Freunde”]
Symphony No. 9 by Ludwig van Beethoven [or Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony; accept Choral Symphony; prompt on Symphony No. 9 or Ninth Symphony by asking “by what composer?”]
Michael Tippett [or Michael Kemp Tippett] (The oratorio is A Child of Our Time.)
parts: Name this word. A set of variations on a theme named after this word includes a “Turkish March.”
The “Ode to Joy” appears in the fourth movement of this symphony, which was the first major symphony to include vocal parts.

This composer’s third symphony quotes the beginning of the fourth movement of Beethoven’s Ninth to critique the optimism of the “Ode to Joy.” This British composer’s other works include an oratorio inspired by Kristallnacht and the opera The Midsummer Marriage.

bonuses.leadin: The Oneida Community newspaper, the Circular, wrote over 500 articles about this project, according to When the Medium Was the Mission. For 10 points each:
answers: first transatlantic telegraph cable [accept Atlantic Telegraph Company; prompt on telegraph or cables] (Paul J. Nahin’s Hot Molecules, Cold Electrons recounts Lord Kelvin’s role in the project.)
Samuel Morse [or Samuel F. B. Morse or Samuel Finley Breese Morse; accept Morse code]
Siemens family [accept Siemens AG; accept Siemens Brothers; accept Werner von Siemens or Ernst Werner Siemens; accept Carl Wilhelm Siemens or Charles William Siemens; accept Alexander Siemens]
parts: Name this project first completed by Cyrus West Field in 1858 using the HMS Agamemnon and USS Niagara. Lord Kelvin was knighted after the 1866 replacement of this project, whose insulation was ruined by high voltage.
This inventor, who invested in Field’s cable-laying Atlantic Telegraph Company, demonstrated the technology in 1844 by sending the message “what hath God wrought” by telegraph from Baltimore to DC.

Cousins from this German family sent the CS Faraday to lay another transatlantic cable in 1874. This family’s namesake company built Hobart’s electric trams and completed the Indo-European cable from London to Calcutta.

bonuses.leadin: This artist created pink-painted ceramic vulva shapes in her work Sweet Sixteen. For 10 points each:
answers: Hannah Wilke [or Arlene Hannah Butter]
Georgia O’Keeffe [or Georgia Totto O’Keeffe]
Janelle Monáe [or Janelle Monáe Robinson]
parts: Name this creator of the S.O.S Starification Object Series, in which she took pictures of herself with dozens of tiny bubblegum vulva sculptures stuck to her body.
Although she denied the symbolism, this modernist American painter is known for paintings of flowers such as Pink Sweet Peas that greatly resemble vulvas.

Duran Lantink designed pink pants that look like vulvas for the terribly-sapphic video for this artist’s song “Pynk.” This artist starred as Jane 57821 in the “emotion picture” that accompanies her album Dirty Computer.

bonuses.leadin: Adherents of this sect argue that the death of the man who names it was faked by his father Ja’far al-Sadiq. For 10 points each:
answers: Isma’ilism [or al-ʾIsmāʿīlīyah; prompt on, BUT DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL, Shi’a]
Shi’a [accept Shi’ism]
al-Azhar Mosque [or al-Jāmiʿ al-ʾAzhar, accept al-Azhar University or al-Jāmiʿat al-ʾAzhar]
parts: Name this Islamic sect. The successful proselytization efforts by several da’i missionaries of this sect led rival authorities to issue the Baghdad Manifesto to try to disprove genealogical claims made by a dynasty of this sect.
Isma’ili became the dominant sect of this branch of Islam during the Fatimid Caliphate. Adherents of this second-largest branch of Islam feuded with the Sunni Abbasid Caliphate.

The Fatimids established this first mosque in Cairo as a center of Isma’ili learning. This mosque is named for a title of Fatima and shares its name with a university in Cairo that was re-established by Gamal Abdel Nasser.

bonuses.leadin: A set of values denoted delta-sub-l that reflect the shift in this property after scattering are used in partial wave analysis to rewrite the scattering function in the spherical basis. For 10 points each:
answers: phase shift [or phase factors]
imaginary part [accept Im]
probability [accept probability current, probability flux; accept probability density function, prompt on pdf]
parts: Name this property that partially characterizes wavefunctions. Stationary states in quantum mechanics evolve by changing this property by a factor of e to the negative i over h-bar times energy times time.

Decomposition into partial waves is an easy method of proving the optical theorem, which states that the scattering cross section equals four pi over k times this function of the zero-angle forward scattering amplitude.

Transmission and reflection coefficients in quantum scattering are reformulated as ratios of this thing’s current. A normalized wavefunction is commonly interpreted as this thing’s density function, which integrates to 1.

bonuses.leadin: The Neolithic Yǎngsháo culture industrially cultivated hemp and these trees, which provide the common name of a related “paper” tree whose fibers furnished Austronesian tapa barkcloth. For 10 points each:
answers: mulberry trees [or Morus; or shèn or rèn; accept white mulberry or Morus alba or sāngshù or sāngmù; accept paper mulberry or Broussonetia papyrifera; prompt on Moraceae]
Assam [accept Assam silk; accept Ahom kingdom]
Maurya Empire [or Mauryan Empire; accept Chandragupta Maurya]
parts: Name these trees planted in groves by the Kingdom of Khotan, apocryphally after a princess hid their leaves in her headdress. The Yellow Emperor’s wife Léizǔ legendarily observed animals eating the leaves of these trees.

Pat silkworms fed on mulberry in this modern state, which also made eri and muga wild silks under a kingdom founded by a Tai prince. The Allahabad Pillar in Uttar Pradesh lists the ancient Ḍavāka and Kāmarūpa kingdoms in this other Indian state.

Weavers in Assam and Bengal produced dukūla “bark silk” that is mentioned in the Arthashāstra, a political manual that was possibly taught at a “university” in Taxila under this empire founded by Chandragupta.

bonuses.leadin: Audiences of Colley Cibber’s (“SIB-er’s”) play Love’s Last Shift went wild for a scene in which an enormous object of this type belonging to Sir Novelty Fashion is carried on stage in a sedan chair. For 10 points each:
answers: wigs [accept periwigs or perruques]
John Vanbrugh
Spain [or Kingdom of Spain or Reino de España; accept The Spanish Tragedy]
parts: Name this sort of prop. Actors playing “fops” in Restoration period comedies often wore elaborate, powdered examples of these accessories over their hair.

In this author’s play The Relapse, Sir Novelty Fashion, now called Lord Foppington, is fitted for a wig so large it will serve as a “hat and cloak in all weathers.” This Restoration polymath also wrote The Provoked Wife.

Beaumond is said to take “more care” of his wig than his bride in Aphra Behn’s sequel to The Rover, which, unlike the original, is set in this country. The character of Revenge appears in a Thomas Kyd play set in this country.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about the Wolff–Kishner reaction, for 10 points each.
answers: carbonyls [prompt on double bonds]
nitrogen gas [or N2]
Huang Minlon [or Huang Minlon modification; accept Huang-Minlon or Huáng Mínglóng]
parts: The reaction can reduce these functional groups to methylenes, removing them after they have served their synthetic purpose. The location of this functional group distinguishes aldehydes from ketones.
Many modifications to the Wolff–Kishner reduction pre-prepare the hydrazone intermediate, which is deprotonated by harsh basic conditions before decomposing to extrude this diatomic molecule.

This Chinese chemist’s full name is sometimes erroneously hyphenated in his widely adopted modification of the reaction. This chemist found that distilling the reaction removed water and sped it up by orders of magnitude.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about African-initiated churches, for 10 points each.
answers: Ethiopian [accept Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church]
Pentecostalism
Ghana [or Republic of Ghana]
parts: The church with this place-based descriptor has the full name of “[this word] Orthodox Tewahedo Church.” The Orthodox church of this name claims to possess the Ark of the Covenant.
Many later African independent churches are influenced by this type of Christianity which emphasizes direct contact with the Holy Spirit and began at the Azusa Street Revival in 1906.

Peter Anim was an early Pentecostal evangelist from this country. Sankofa (“SAHN-ko-fa”), the symbol of a bird looking over its back, originated in this country and is used by its Afrikania new religious movement.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Giacomo Puccini’s attempts to incorporate authentic local musical traditions into his operas, for 10 points each.
answers: The Girl of the Golden West [or The Girl of the West or La fanciulla del West]
“Mò Lì Huā” [or “Jasmine Flower”]
Madama Butterfly [or Madame Butterfly]
parts: Puccini used a Zuni melody collected by ethnomusicologist Carlos Troyer in Jake Wallace’s song in this opera, which follows the title female protagonist during the California Gold Rush.

In Turandot, Puccini quoted this Chinese folk song, which a children’s chorus sings after the Act I invocation to the moon. This song, whose title references a flower, begins with the pentatonic melody “E [pause], E, G, A, C, C, A, G.”
This Puccini opera quotes the folk tune “Miyasan” during the arrival of the wealthy Yamadori in its second act. This opera’s title character commits seppuku after Pinkerton renounces her.

bonuses.leadin: Janet Hartley’s 2021 history of this river explores its personification as a “mother” and reports a 16th-century ruler ordering its whipping. For 10 points each:
answers: Volga River [accept Mother Volga or Volga-Matushka; accept Kazanka River; accept Povolzhye; accept The Volga: A History of Russia’s Greatest River]
Nizhny Novgorod [accept Gorky; reject “Novgorod” or “Veliky Novgorod”]
meat [accept specific meats like veal or beef or chicken; accept butchery or animal slaughter; prompt on food or animals or similar answers, prompt on hunting; reject “fur”]
parts: Name this long Russian river whose Tatar trade centers of Kazan and Astrakhan were conquered by Ivan the Terrible.

This city on the Volga drew Persian merchants to its annual trade fair at Makaryev Monastery. A cathedral in this city is named for Alexander Nevsky, a prince of the medieval republic it partially shares a name with.

Kuzma Minin, who traded this good in Nizhny Novgorod, fought Poland’s invasion of Russia after a 1601 famine. Dmitry Pozharsky names a preparation of this stuff, which is mainly reserved for holidays in the Domostroi.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about genetic technologies that enable pooled screening of thousands of genotype/phenotype pairs in a single run.
answers: RNAi [or RNA interference; prompt on post-transcriptional gene silencing; prompt on gene knockdowns; do not accept or prompt on gene knockouts]
CRISPR/Cas9 [or clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats]
lentiviruses [accept Lenti-X; prompt on retroviruses]
parts: This endogenous gene perturbation system commonly used in pooled screens introduces hairpin structures into cells. Components of this system such as Dicer are found in the RISC complex.

Screens are now often run using this gene editing system that utilizes single guide RNAs and the Cas9 nuclease. Jennifer Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier won the 2020 Nobel in Chemistry for its development.

This type of vector is often used to stably express Cas9 or sgRNAs in CRISPR-based screens. The third generation of these vectors, which can be packaged by 293T cells, improves safety by eliminating the Tat gene.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist pretends that hoarded bread was eaten by mice to a priest who is the second of his many masters in the novel Lazarillo de Tormes, the first modern example of this genre. For 10 points each:
answers: picaresque novels [or picaresca]
being blind [or word forms; accept Blindness or Ensaio sobre a cegueira; accept any answers that indicate a lack of ability to see]
The Unfortunate Traveller [or The Unfortunate Traveller: or, the Life of Jack Wilson]
parts: Name this genre that centers on a roguish, young hero who relies on their street smarts. This genre originated in the Spanish Golden Age.
Lazarillo’s first master is a man who prays for a living and has this condition. The doctor’s wife is the only one to [emphasize] not have this condition in a José Saramago novel titled for it.

The protagonist of this first picaresque novel from Britain is targeted by the Papal Physician, who wishes to use his body for science. This novel ends with Jack Wilson fleeing Italy with his wife Diamante.

bonuses.leadin: A book titled for this animal analyzes how members of minorities vote based on “linked fate.” For 10 points each:
answers: mules [accept “forty acres and a mule” or Behind the Mule]
heuristics [accept availability heuristic or representativeness heuristic or black utility heuristic; prompt on biases]
control [accept controlling images or social control]
parts: A Michael Dawson book is titled “behind” what animal? Advocates of reparations often reference the unfulfilled promise to provide freed slaves with “forty acres” and one of these farm animals.

Behind the Mule describes one of these constructs that uses group utility as a proxy for individual utility. Rose McDermott’s work analyzes politics with these things, such as the “representativeness” and “availability” ones.

Patricia Collins’s Black Feminist Thought analyzes “the mule” as an “image” with this function. Travis Hirschi’s theory of criminology is named for the “social” form of this concept, which discourages delinquency.

bonuses.leadin: According to Jared Diamond, “the single most astonishing fact of human geography” is that Madagascar’s Merina people are most closely related to this country’s Dayak people. For 10 points each:
answers: Indonesia [or Republic of Indonesia or Républik Indonesia]
cloves [or cengkeh; or jirofo; prompt on spices]
bamboo [or awi or butuh; or volo; accept specific bamboo species]
parts: Name this country that archaeologists have culturally linked to Madagascar by examining the resemblance of Malagasy boats to those of Madura, the similarity of words like nosy (“noose”) and nusa, and the spread of xylophones.

Indonesia and Madagascar are the top two producers of vanilla and this commodity. It’s not tobacco, but due to its high quality in Madagascar, Indonesia imports this crop from Madagascar to make kretek cigarettes.

The valiha is a tube zither and national symbol of Madagascar made of this plant. The Indonesian celempung (“CHUH-lum-poong”) features in the gamelan ensemble and is also made of this fast-growing woody grass.
